title: Raspberry Pi Case and Cluster Files

description.text:
This is a case designed for the Raspberry Pi B+ and Raspberry Pi 2 computer. The case is entirely passively cooled. You can print 2 base boards and four outside locks to create a case for a single Raspberry Pi, or use a combination of the baseboards and locks to connect a number of units together to form a Beowulf cluster of your chosen size.

This case design was originally designed for my Parallel computing course. I never ended up using the files for the course, since the Parallella board became available to purchase last July (see my other contribution for Parallella case files). We did use this design to create a 21 node raspberry pi cluster (pictured), which two of my students have used for independent study work . Neither student reported any issues with the cluster overheating.

Credits:
The case was co-designed by Suzanne J. Matthews and William ("Frank") Blackmon.

comments.text: Excellent! Let me know how it goes! To ensure a smooth fit, you may want to adjust the quality of the printing of your parts. I have found that printing the connectors on the highest setting (smoothest finish) can cause them to fall out of the holes. We print the the connectors a little coarser than the base boards. It's worth experimenting with your settings to figure out what works best.

title: Component Tester Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: The specific board I used is no longer available as it is an older design and the newer boards no longer fit this case. So use this design as a concept rather than print it.

This case will enclose a component tester like this one sold on ebay. It is specific to the button layout and screen layout.

It will require heat insert nuts and a small piece of foam.

If you find my designs useful, please help by donating.

You can print this without scaffolding, but I would recommend a brim if you have edge adhesion problems as you want the surfaces completely flat.

To assemble:
1) print the case
2) prepare the case
a) place a small foam piece where the battery lays, this will help secure it and stop any rattle.
b) insert nuts heat insert nuts using old soldering iron to the top of case
3) separate the component tester by removing the screws and stand off posts; retain two of the tapered head screws
4) build a cable (5" long is good) that will connect the screen board to the main board.
5) Snap screen into the top, it will be a snug fit.
6) place the main board into place, it will be held down when the enclosure is secured.
7) using the tapered screws, assemble the two halfs.

Oh, don't forget the battery!

author: Makuna

description.text:
Before Printing Please Refer To Instructions

All you need is a standard small DC motor and a couple of wide Popsicle sticks! Put the sticks into the hub and the motor in the body. The rest is up to you!

Apply power to the motor to make a fan.

Read the motor leads with a fan blowing at the turbines blades for a wind power experiment.

I am sorry for the letters in the base. This was originally for an alternative energy sources project.

If you have any questions or requests let me know!

NOTE: The Hub is not the propeller by itself. You MUST insert Popsicle sticks in the sides for it to function

Print the Hub with the largest FLAT face DOWN.

Print the body so that the front face of the motor case is on the same plane as the front edge of the base.
It should look like you are printing an arc

This is Gangsta Chess! Now you can wage your own criminal underground turf war in your home!
This design is a mashup/derivative based on the original gangsta, created by the OG himself, Yzorg.
I designed this as an entry to a design challenge that was created to settle a friendly disagreement between MakerBlock and I. I guess this is how makers settle disputes!
Each gangsta has his own special chess style hat (or replacement head for the knight) to signify which piece he is. He also has a piece logo on his shirt, to make it easier to identify the pieces, because there is nothing more frustrating than playing chess with pieces that are hard to identify or not instantly recognizable.
Unfortunately, the deadline for the challenge is coming up really fast, so I was only able to print up the black pieces minus pawns. I expect to use Z scaled down gangstas for pawns.
The files were created in OpenScad. I have uploaded the file, but the code isn't that clean. 
Thanks to Syvwlch and MakerBlock for their advice during creation.
 Update:

Print each set twice, obviously in different colors. One set consists of: 2 Rooks
2 knights
2 Bishops
1 King
1 Queen
8 Pawns Then, play some Gangsta Chess!

description.text: You'll have seen a few of these captive sphere models here on Thingiverse, so there's nothing especially new about this one. Except that it's the result of a tutorial explaining how to get started with OpenSCAD, as published on my blog 3D Genius: http://www.3dgeni.us/getting-started-with-openscad/ The tutorial starts from scratch and explains the basics of working with this most useful of design programs. The whole thing is described in just 10 lines of code, so if you ever wondered what OpenSCAD was all about, now's your chance to find out.

Here's the OpenSCAD code in full: $fn=50;
difference() {
cube(30, center=true);
sphere(19);
}
difference() {
sphere(16);
translate ([0,0,-30])
cube([12,12,30], center=true);
} If you want to know what it all means, check out the tutorial!

The Thingummies are little creatures. They are active and sociable.
Here they catch the wind and form an original weathervane .
Put it in your garden or in your balcony and cheer them up !
This thing is very easy to make and to put in place, see the instructions.
Have a look to other Thingummies in my collection " The Thingummies "

This thing is composed by three independent elements, about 15 cm long and 8 mm high.
They have two little rings which allow them to rotate around a thread ( nylon thread, one or more, spring or other . ).
You have just to thread the elements, starting from the upper one, and to make some knots under the lower ring of each element,
in order to fix the level.
Finally you have to fix the thread up and down. Take care of your safety when you make it !

comments.text: How do you get them to stick?

they do not stick. They have two little rings and they rotate freely around a nylon thread . You should make a knot under the lower ring of each element., in order to substain the element.

Leap and JR Ninja Props

Conic BÃ©zier Curve for OpenSCAD
also known as Quadratic Bezier Curve
also known as Bezier Curve with 3 control points
also known as 'Conic Arcs' or 'Parabolic Segments'
By Don B, 2011, released into the Public Domain What's it for Bezier curves allow you to pick a small number of 'control points', then let the computer fill in a pretty curve between them. In this thing, 3 control points are used. Notes This is for 3-point bezier curves; there is another popular type, the 4-point 'Cubic', that this code doesn't do. This is inspired by William Adam's cubic bezier Thingiverse OpenSCAD code. His code now also handles Conics; I guess I will leave this thing here as a sort of 'super simple' 'for dummies' version. The first sample image shows a simple 3 control-point curved polygon, and a rod around which it can be rotated. The result of this rotation is shown in the big smooth object. The next sample image shows the code itself; the module is only about 10 lines long thanks to OpenSCAD's built-in vector math. Please see also http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8443 by William A Adams (Cubic Beziers)
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bezier_2_big.gif by Phil Tregoning
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve by Wikipedia editors
http://www.freetype.org/freetype2/docs/glyphs/glyphs-6.html David Turner + Freetype team Using the code
  • download the .scad file, below
  • copy/paste the BezConic module to your own code
  • call it like this:
    • p0=[15,0];
    p1=[1,14];
    p2=[7,30];
    linear_extrude() BezConic(p0,p1,p2,steps=20); Fun Facts BÃ©zier are named after Pierre BÃ©zier, who used the work of Paul de Casteljau to make curves on car bodies. Casteljau worked at Citroen and Bezier worked at Renault. They are named 'conic' because 3-point Bezier's are basically parabolas. A parabola is basically the intersection of a cone with a plane (i.e. a conic section). Please see wikipedia for more info. Conic Arc BÃ©zier Curves (3 control points) are used by TrueType fonts.
An example .stl file is included just for giggles.

title: Feeder for Spring loaded extruder with PTFE and pneumatic fitting V1.4

description.text:
Feeder for MasonStoneHenge Spring loaded extruder with PTFE support and pneumatic fitting for a M5 thread and for a 9.3mm thread like the one of the hot-end itself (untested). This is my first remix so it is maybe not perfect but it should do the job just fine.

V1.4 Small design fixes. The 9.3mm version is untested yet.

V1.3: Small hole now end directly at the end of the pneumatic fitting. The filament sometimes got stuck in the pocket that was left between the small hole and the large hole. Also the filament missed sometimes the entry of the fitting. That ends in chaos as the extruder motor tried to extrude but the filament was stucked, break and the rest parts was laying in this pocket, blocking the extruder and hard to clean. Should be fixed right now.

Previous changes:
V1.1: Hole diameter for the PTFE tube increased to match OD4. Hole for the pneumatic fitting slightly widened for easier mounting.

I added V1.2 if you need a slightly more diameter for the tube (for example ABS printing and shrinking) but please try V1.1 first.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Ormerod

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

You should use ABS for printing.

comments.text: So I found after long testing a little designing issue. The inner hole should be let completely to the pneumatic fitting entrance. I will fix this these days.

title: US Western locomotive 1_scale 1:32
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model that is inspired by various Western locomotive models. it is a working motorized model. see the film here
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gmnInLuiID0
I have used the LGB motor with worm gear at both ends, see pictures last in line

At first I thought to have Led in the lantern. Then I found small bulbs for 18-24 V, which gives an old impression of light.

I have attached a PDF that you can twist and turn the Locomotive, in Adobe Reader
Locomotive's length from the rear cab edge to cow catcher tip is 330mm
Loco Tender you will find at this link
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:893402

The locomotive have i printed in a Replicator 2x with default settings. Both ABS and PLA, prefer ABS in certain situations where it is easy to glue with acetone. Suggests that the axes printed in ABS and Acetone glued.
The shaft, these are supposed to be round, therefore, should it be lathed for you who has one.
Otherwise, put the shaft in a drill, sand it reasonably round

I have been using small screws to put together the model.see the pictures.
To side rod I used 4mm machine screw.
The hole in the wheels is threaded with a 4mm threaded pin.

Do not do the whole screw hole, without save a little at the end
so that the screw locking.
otherwise it will be be unscrewed when you run the locomotive.

to the Handrails, I took 2mm brass tube, bell I found in a hobby shop made of brass

title: Pasting Table Accessories
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Whether you're going to farmers' markets to flog your questionably-shaped carrots, on the streets to push your pinko-eco-commie-hippie agenda, or just having a bake sale to fund your hackerspace / D&D club / moon 'laser', at some point or other you can almost guarantee that whoever was in charge of aquiring materials for said venture went to the nearest DIY/art store and got one of those horribly flimsy wooden pasting tables, because they were the cheapest option (in a monetary system). Then, assuming you go and use that thing every other weekend, within 5 years you will likely have gone through about 3 of them, as they rapidly fall apart when careless individuals bash the corners of them on everything during transit, causing the staples holding the top together to come away, and lean or rest heavy things on the middle, causing the hinge to pull apart.
Of course, had you the funds and forethought to cough up for a portable aluminium table to begin with, it would have cost you just as much as those 3 wooden tables, but still be in working order. But if like me you're currently stuck with one, fear not, for now we can extend the life of that pathetic bit of wood at low cost with some printable modifications! If you'll tell me what has broken on your table, we can keep making replacement parts for it until the resulting supporter-of-things is more PLA-Wood cyborg than a recognisable pasting table. :D

For everyone's sake, use PLA for these parts, so that when your enhanced table eventually dies its unrecoverable mutated death from failure in parts you can't replace, at least every bit of it will be biodegradable if you don't manage to salvage the attachments before your colleague carelessly throws it in a bin.

  • Protect your bumpable table corners with printable corner protectors, by fixing them on with a woodscrew.

  • Replace fatigued hinges with the pair provided.

    • I'm not sure what would make the best easily available pin for the hinge, but you might be able to get away with a scrap piece of dowel or metal rod with something flat glued to either end. Otherwise I'll have to design some kind of printable snap-together rivet for the joint.
  • Keep the thin board clamped down well to the frame using the side protectors, and use accessory versions to hang signs or attach clips for leaflets or other contraptions.
    • The 'clip' version of this is likely to change, as I think there must be much better ways of holding things down to the table than what I currently have in mind, which is an average clothes peg, but I just haven't thought of it yet.
    • N.B. if attaching some gadget to the side, be sure to use the side with the handle, so that it doesn't catch on things while you carry the table.
    • Of course, we can always try to keep replacing bits of these tables with scrap wood from skips, too, especially if parts of the frame wear out, but good luck to anyone with one.

author: 4ndy

description.text:
This is my first attempt at designing an end effector for the ZeGo delta bot. This is a basic holder for a pen with a 12mm barrel. The 6 magnets are: 15mm x 5mm with a 5mm rounded hole, N50 Neodymium.
The magnet pattern does not exactly match the original ZeGo pattern, and is overall a bit larger.
To improve the holding power of the magnets, I threaded six M4x5 hex socket set screws from the bottom surface up through each ring magnet. This technique is similar to the original ZeGo design.

title: PrintrBoard Raspberry Pi Enclosure w/ Fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When I upgraded my PrintrBot Simple Metal Silver with a hotbed it caught on fire! YIKES! So I moved my PrintrBoard out from under the hotbed to reduce the resistance in the power cable caused by increased heat which caused the fire by creating an increasing cycle of heat and resistance. Well having a PrintrBoard just sitting on my desk was not safe either, plus it presented a couple of opportunities to make an enclosure for my Printrboard, include a cooling fan and also cool and enclose my Raspberry Pi that I use as a slave for my PrintrBot using AstroPi from AstroBox.

I have a Rev.D Printrboard (works with Rev.F6 w/ micro USB) and a Raspberry Pi 2 or 3, so the files are specific to these hardware. I also included versions without logos, as well as the logo files in AutoCAD format. If you do make modifications, please post pictures of your ReMix, it is always fun to see other peoples customization of a design.

Some files include insets for nuts. I based all of the hardware on 3mm bolts and nuts except for the Raspberry Pi 2 mounts which are 2.5mm. If a nut inset is not present it is because I usually use a tap for those holes as ABS and PLA both tap very well.

It is worth noting that to use this enclosure as I have designed it I am drilling a 19mm (~3/4 inch) hole in the side of my PrintrBot Simple Metal Silver for access to the cables. After you print your parts they can be used to mark the hole placement right where you would like it to be mounted.

Printing the enclosure will require printing support material. In my experience I have liked the freeware MatterControl for their support material feature Support Everywhere which allows support material to be started within the part and not originate from the print bed. For those of you lucky enough to have the paid for software Simplify3D, this feature is also available.

Enjoy-
Matt

UPDATED 11/06/2017
Added STEP (.stp) files for anyone who would like to modify this design. STEP files open in a variety of different CAD packages including AutoDesk's FREE Fusion 360.

Read the description for any details related to assembling or building this Thing.

You don't have to print all the parts! Just use the ones you want, some are variations of the same part. Some are just logos for fun.

title: Gadgets3D LCD mount for Prusa i2

description.text:
I did not find any holders for Gadgets3D LCD panel, so I created my own. As you may guess, I like simplistic and sleek design :) It mounts at the end of the top rods, and swivels a bit. BOM:
  • 5 x 20 mm M3 screw
  • 5 x M3 washer
  • 5 x M3 nut

• Print the parts
  • Insert LCD part into Z end part, add 20 mm screw, washer and nut
  • Mount LCD using 4 M3 20 mm screws and 4 washers & nuts
  • Enjoy!

When printed with flex filament, this thing is a durable elastic landing gear for the RCExplorer Tricopter. Instead of relying on breaking zip-ties, the elasticity of the landing gears should protect the copter from all but the heaviest landings.

The blade-like boom-attached landing gears are too wobbly to work on their own, but in this case, they're only needed on the front booms to balance the copter. Two of the main landing gears, glued or zip-tied to the bottom of the battery tray, will take the main load.

Additionally, the landing gear increases the ground clearance of the copter, which should help when a camera gimbal has been attached in front of the copter.

The drawback of this landing gear is the increased weight. Compared to the original one, this landing gear is about 30 grams heavier. The side landing gears weight 9.6 g, whereas the original ones are 5 g. The main landing gear is 13.8 g per piece. With more than enough power to spare, I'm happy to pay the price, though.
Print two of each files using flex filament. I used 20% infill. Attach the side landing gears with zip-ties and glue the main ones to the battery tray. That's it!

Check out my Lottery Scratcher Tool! The tool removes wide strips of material with each stroke and will clean a Scratcher Ticket in a just a few strokes. The Cutting Head is designed to remove material with forward or backward strokes and is designed for right or left hand use. How does it work so well? It’s about the shape of the cutting head; it cuts a wide swath and channels derbies away at the same time.
I have provided several to choose from.

  1. “Lucky Quarter Scratcher”, go ahead and snap in your favorite quarter and still keep that luck in your hand!
  2. “Basic Scratcher”, just like a quarter but has a duel cutting head on it. Basic Scratcher can snap into the Lucky Quarter Scratcher making a four headed scratching tool.
  3. “Mini Scratcher”. Same as others, just really small.
  4. “Four Leaf Clover Scratcher”. Nothing like the luck of the Irish! LOL
    Note: Supports built into the parts; just snap them off after printing. And I have printed these parts on a Acrylic Table with Tape and on a Heated Table with Kapton. Prints work fine both ways.
    Enjoy, Reamo

author: thomasdr

title: Bang and Olufsen Beovox CX100 Repair kit

description.text:
Last year I created the front fabric frames to fit new fabric to my Beovox CX100's: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:365459
This year I decided to refoam them (badly needed):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zV6s3_Cb0xg
But I did not have a turntable to fix the speakers to, so I designed one to 3D print. Note: This is not intended for long term use, but it works!
So now I had new front fabric, new foam surrounds but how to connect the speaker wire? A 3D printable DIN41529 female replacement plug while you shop for the real plug is included here as well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uFnH759eMnA&hd=1

The front frames needs support and once printed, can be fitted with flexible jersey fabric in a color of your choice.

The speaker spinner needs one 608 ball bearing (roller skate bearings) to turn smoothly. Print the spinner holder with 3-4 shells to make it stiff enough to support the bearing and the weight of the speaker. EDIT: Replaced the pictures of the old version of the spinner to match the .stl files included here.

The DIN41529 plug is not intended for long term use but if you, like me, did not get a plug with the speakers and need to try them immidiately, print a couple and wire them up!

author: SimonFront

title: DJI Phantom 3 Filter ring, holds ND filter gels on existing camera.

description.text:
This Neutral Density filter ring is designed for the DJI Phantom 3. Included is a 3D printed ring to hold the ND filters in front of the existing lens on the Phantom. This ring is designed for a 31mm diameter ND filter gel. Simply choose the ND filter/s that you need for the exposure you want and stack them against the Phantom camera and install the ring to keep them in place.

Here is a YouTube video on how to use them
https://youtu.be/0TbDhJvIUvA

I am selling a pre-cut filter set for this thing on eBay.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/-/272214170861?

It includes:

  • one 3-stop ND filter (3 stops darker)
  • one 2-stop ND filter
  • one 1-stop ND filter

If you want to purchase a set already made you can do that on my website at www.ditzco.com.

The darkest filter is 3-stops. On a bright overcast day in high sun this might be enough for 1080p/60. On a very bright day 4-stops is typical at 1080P. This would be the darkest filter (3-stops) and the lightest filter (1-stop). Because the max 4K frame rate is 30fps you will probably need to darken the image one stop when you go from 1080P to 4K.

The shutter speed should be double the frame rate.
For example:
1080P/60 = 1/120 second
4k/30 = 1/60 second

3D printed ring and one filter only weigh 0.7 grams.

I made it with the default settings. Print the wider part of the ring down. It was created with OnShape.com

If your filter ring does not fit please resize accordingly in your slicing software and print again. I have made over 3,000 of these rings and they do fit. They are sized perfectly for my MakerBot Gen3 clone with PolyMAX. Your millage may very.

title: Flag stand! Honoring our great nations!

description.text:
All people live under a flag, where ever we live, we find our patriotism and inspiration through the fluttering of our national / organizational Colors. Whether that be the Canadian, American, Mexican, British, German, Czech, Russian, Brazilian, the list goes on and on.

Here I have designed this to hold my 4"6" American, USN, USMC, and the POW/MIA flags.
The flag stand has seven slots for flags with a stick diameter of 8mm.

This is the PERFECT table topper for a cookout! Independence Day maybe? Bonfire? Cinco De Mayo?? Parties?

In the bottom of the model I have designed two slots to fit the American Quarter. It may be better to insert the coin as the print is printing. As the bridging may make the fit difficult if done otherwise. If you decided to do that, insert coin at layer 20.

.2mm layers
Bridging 30mm Min

author: SouthGeometric

description.text:
MakeItFloat competition

The boat is still in its planning stages and this is just a rough idea on how it will look like and how it will work.

This is one of my first designs ever so if you have any tips to improve my design please comment or just like it so i know that theirs actually interest an il have it printed at 3dhubs .

The rotater floatater is a wind up boat that runs on the spring that is installed in the boat.

the boat makes use of a pelton turbine in order to be more efficient in its running.

I have also decided to design it as a displacement hull for it to be more stable ,carry more weight and can go at higher speeds.

The design is made as light as possible as the hull is completely hollow

my main focus is on the amount of weight it can take and the overall look and movement of the boat.

The stl file is just a image of the overall design i will start putting each component out as soon as i get a suitable design for them.

thanks for reading and please any advice will be useful

i want t thank gzumwalt for the spring motor design and fittan for the pelton wheel.

Fluid membrane bilayer of phospholipids. PDB converted to STL using my software, Meshlab, and UCSF Chimera. http://3vee.molmovdb.org/simple3dPrint.php
Based on the model from:

Helmut Heller, Michael Schaefer, Klaus Schulten "Molecular dynamics simulation of a bilayer of 200 lipids in the gel and in the liquid crystal phase", J. Phys. Chem., 1993, 97 (31), pp 8343–8360 DOI: 10.1021/j100133a034

Coloring chosen to highlight different molecules. Polar vs. hydrophobic regions did not work as color separation.

title: low res hi quality vases on ultimaker

description.text:
Single walled low res hi quality vases. Big one more than 220mm high, printed is 1.5 hour...!
see also www.facebook.com/europerminutedesign

The trick:
  • use a 0.8 mm nozzle [instead of standard 0.4mm]
  • print with layerheight 0.4
  • now the difficult part: first 2 layers printed with fill [set layer 0 to 2 in carve menu]
  • from layer 2 - 99999 printed without fill [also set in carve menu]
  • merge both files in text editor, make sure you add G92 E0 (zero the extruded length) just before the second part and cut away the gcode you don't need
  • heat up and go!
    • tip for skeinforge developpers: will it be possible to 'chain' profiles in the future...?

Featured on the teklalabs print my lab contest winners. Sterilize with ethanol before use. I'm told that you can print autoclavable parts with nylon but have not tried.

http://www.teklalabs.org/print-my-lab-results/

Description: Experimental protocols can require sampling from 12 to 36 tubes at short intervals. Unfortunately, the standard tube lids friction fit on and the entire tube must be removed, uncapped and replaced. Furthermore all 36 caps must be set down in a sterile place and without mixing caps between tubes to prevent cross‐tube contamination. The time it takes to do this is unacceptable in some cell culture experiments.

By linking 6 caps together that are just loose enough to be removed without too much force, an entire row of caps can be removed in one motion! This reduces sampling time from minutes to seconds, and helps to prevent cross-contamination, simplifying collection of data that is otherwise too difficult to obtain.

Print holes side up.

Exotic materials may be autoclavable but normal ABS and PLA are not. sterilize by spraying or soaking in ethanol.

I recommend sealing surface voids by painting, fogging, or dipping in acetone (ABS) or methylene chloride (PLA). This helps close surface pores preventing spilled media from getting stuck and turning the part brown.

title: aMESS RAMPS Flattened Enclosure v.0.1.2 - Arduino Modular Enclosure System Stack

description.text:
This enclosure is designed to house the RAMPS electronics for RepRap, a 50mm fan for cooling the Pololu stepper drivers and mosfets, and an optional LCD display in the lid.  It should work with v1.1, and 1.2 RAMPS, and other shields designed for the Arduino MEGA that have the 2" x 4" footprint.
Side mounting clamps are designed to attach to 5/16" or M8 threaded rod, with plastic ties.
Cable access is through the front of the enclosure, but there is also a hidden slot built in to the side wall, in case there are shorter cables that cannot make the long way around to the front.
Can be mounted almost anywhere, but my preference is the back left corner of the machine (Prusa).
Print all six parts, check for good fit, and glue.  The fan can be connected to the 12VDC header located just above the D1 Diode.

I wanted to build a prototype of a miniature wind rotor that takes advantage of the lift of the wings of airplanes.
I think the result satisfactory
eerste probeersel, en de tweede

I've finally finished my quadcopter design. This is NOT A RECOMMENDED design for beginners, also I don't recommend to experienced either :)

My first dream was to make a small quad, smaller than 200 gr. and have advanced features like image processing etc. but finally this 410 gr. (AUW) monster came up. It has Naze 32 controller, Afro ESC's, 12-5v DC DC converter, 3S 20C lipo battery, Turnigy i6A reciever (and transmitter of course), DYS BE-1806 outrunners, 5030 props. All the placeholders are designed for this parts, and won't fit other parts. The two tubes are 10 (od) - 8 (id) CF tubes. I didn't want to cut tubes half and lose integrity. Outside the quad is a cable heaven, and inside is a cable harness hell!

Anyway, that's it :) I hope you like it.

description.text:
This is a hydroplane boat (or thunderboat) toy. I base myself off the "Banshee X" boat in the arcade game "Hydro Thunder Hurricane". I then added a car like spoiler. The boat is approximately 14 cm long (5.5 inch) and 6 cm wide (2 and 1/3 inch). It is a single print design and it can be printed in 2 hours.

I had to make change to the first design in order to make it stand on its stern, have enough surface that touch the bed print for adhesion and print without support material. This 3rd revision is nice looking and it float.

I have 2 successful ABS print. They stand near 22 grams. The waterline when still is at the widest part of the hull. Since hydroplane rely on the planing force, rather then the buoyancy, I was only able to put 4 penny before it sink.

I hope you enjoy this toy.

For best result print with
rotate part to print on its stern
0.8 perimeters
2 or more raft layers for added adhesion to bed
8% or more infill
No support material is required

comments.text: Does this float well?
comments.author: Lannid

comments.text:
It does float.
My 50% version seam to rely on surface tension more than buoyancy.
The 100% scale is a little tail heavy for my taste but it does look true to a hydroplane boat.
I also made a 150% version and the gain in volume didn't cost much of weight, so it floats even better.

title: Z Axis height Adjustment for LS3020 Laser Cutter

description.text:
Just as title really! A handy wheel used for adjusting the height of the table externally. Mine came with a small aluminium knob that fits on the inside, but its a pain to easily adjust.
This fits on the M10 studding under the machine, and is pretty much the same size as the A4 working area! (You can see where I missed a bit :p)
Really simple mod, and much much easier to adjust the bed height!
Sticks out about 5-6mm out from front of machine. Mine was purchased from HPC Laser http://hpclaser.co.uk/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=40 so I would imagine it fits most, if not all machines of this type.

• Load into preferred laser cutter software
  • Cut!
  • Remove from laser cutter.
  • Using the 2 M10 nuts, fix wheel onto protruding studding under machine, tighten both nuts together as shown.
  • ????
  • Profit!

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple 1405 "TRI ROD MOD" with or without XL tower upgrade (first 1405 XL tower)

title: Improved Tri Rod Mod Extruder Mount (Printrbot Simple 1405)

description.text:
The original extruder mount for the tri rod mod has a very thin attachment point and only uses 3 of the 4 screws possible to attach alu extruder. I noticed that over time, the original mount would bend back under the motor's weight with all the nearby heat from the motor since it was so thin. This bending always happened during prints and was extremely frustrating as the bend would cause a y-shift of a few mm.

This improved version features holes to attach the alu extruder in 4 points to distribute the weight better in addition to a much bulkier attachment surface to prevent bending. So far I've only used it for a couple of prints, but it's held up fantastically so far.

You will need to use 4 20mm long screws to attach the extruder (not such a big deal, but it is worth noting). Also, due to the much bulkier attachment surface, you can't use the hot end fan mount in the original version. (That's the hot end fan, not to be confused with the very important part fan that works fine with this version)

comments.text: Would it be best to print this part in Polycarbonate, so it doesn't bend under 200 degrees? I printed it in PLA, and it's still sagging.
comments.author: travisrt

comments.text: Hey, first of all, sorry I totally missed your first comment from over a month ago. I printed this in PLA and still had issues. I imagine this part will work if you print it in another material besides PLA, and polycarbonate would probably work great. To be completely honest, I ended up just putting a Bowden extruder on my printer. (As soon as I can, I'll post the part on thingiverse for a printrbot j head Bowden mount as well as a printrbot Ubis Bowden mount.) Using a Bowden extruder takes almost all of the stress off the hot end mount, and it works pretty well. If you still have issues, I'd recommend looking into using a Bowden extruder.

comments.author: bove2280

comments.text: No problem at all. By J-head bowden extruder, do you mean to say the stepper motor for moving the filament is located away from the extruder mount? The sheer weight of my Nema 17 stepper motor seems to be aggravating the sagging.
comments.author: bove2280

comments.text: Yeah, a Bowden extruder has the stepper motor located away from the hot end. Usually the stepper motor ends up getting put on a fixed position. By separating the hot end from the motor, when the extruder moves, the printer has less weight to move. This generally improves print quality, although if your print bed moves as an axis, you'll still have resonance lines on your prints. Also, you need to make sure your extruder has plenty of torque or else a Bowden extruder will be a disaster. Also, J-head is just a specific brand of hot end.
comments.author: travisrt

comments.text: In this case, with a tri-rod mod printrbot, where did you end up putting the filament extruder? And with what design for the Nema 17 motor? Given the travel distances, have you experienced any retraction issues?

I have included the .thing file for the 5 plates, the individual part files in the .zip, and meshmixer file where is separated the parts.

I just built all 5 plate and used 50C build plate temp on the right extruder at 200C. It is a very tight fix on the plates. Pay close attention to part to plate edges and where to place the glass clips. (If using glass built plate) I had to move my clips around a little during printing to guarantee no rubbing.

comments.text:
I do not have dxf or pdf of the model.. I used the original stl files and just arranged them to work on the Duplicator 4S build plate.
You might be able to convert the stl to a solid (par, step, prt, etc) and then solid to CAD (dxf or pdf). Try Autodesk Fusion 360 or the other free Autodesk products have built in translators.

description.text:
~Here is a lens hood for the newest version of canons 18-55. This has been specifically designed to work with the new stm version of the lens and will not work with the older non-stm 18-55 3.5-5.6~

Surprisingly, i could not find a lens hood that would work with the new stm version of canon's 18-55 kit lens. The new version has a different bayonet mount with only two locks vs the old versions three. Because there was not one that was already made, i decided to cad up my own and share it so others can easily use this.

You should not need to do anything special to print this. Just make sure that it is pointed upright and use 100% infill. Depending on the material you are using, you may want to scale up the model a bit to account for shrinkage. With colorfabb xt, i found that a 2% increase in scale helped the lenshood fit much better.

description.text:
This is a 30MM cooling fan mount that I made for my Kossel 3D printer. My printer is made with 2020 Extruded aluminum, and the two horizontal pieces on the bottom are 30MM apart (center-to-center), and this is where the RAMPS board is mounted.

Just attach the fan to the mount with some appropriate length M3 screws for your fan, and the mount snaps right into place in the groves on the extruded aluminum. If more tension is needed/desired, you could put something in-between the 'fingers' to give a more snug hold, as it can be pulled out without much effort, but unless you're moving your machine around a lot, it will most likely just stay put. ;-)

I made this bottle mount to hold a 2" ice wine bottle. I drilled a small hole in the side of the bottle, wove in these copper wire LED lights (see below)and then glued the bottle in place into the bottom of the holder. WE thought it turned out pretty nice! Enjoy!

PS: please note this was designed for a 2" O.D., you will need to match or alter accordingly.

Here are the lights we used:
http://tinyurl.com/nrpd6ze

comments.text: Nice!  I made a similar wine bottle light a couple of years ago and now have a vodka bottle wrapped in NeoPixels that I was thinking about making mounts for.  Less than 24 hours after that thought, you published this.  Thanks!

author: JeyC

description.text:
I have made a bunch of improvements in this design, and I would consider it my first real "success".
Changes: 1) I changed the pressure angled of the V-groove from 45 to 22.5 so the v-groove bearing are easier to print.
2) many modifications to the shuttle and added in adjustment screws, slide tracks, etc for mounting
3) changes to the bearing system, I'm now using 608 bearings with a v-groove sleeve.
4) changed the height of the tube, the herrringbone track is now printed separately and inlaid into the track space. My to-do list includes:
-More shuttle modifications
-Mods to the motor mount
-Cleaning up code
-Usage of parametric printed bearings
-get rid of all nuts and bolts and replace with printed materials
Don't build this quite yet, I'm still working on more revisions.

description.text:
This is an adjustable camera mounting assembly for use as an eye tracker. The parts themselves are designed to fit onto an old AR scouter head band, though a custom head band could also be designed and used (work in progress).

There are 11 pieces for the entire assembly:
wolrd_cam_mount - a small piece that fits onto the to top of the AR scouter head band for mounting a world camera.

eye_cam_angled_bracket - main body of the eye tracker mount with arched slot for angular adjustment of eye camera.

eye_tracker_angled_arm - the adjustable arm that attaches to the eye_cam_angled_bracket. Allows angular adjustment of the eye tracking camera.

angled_arm_brace - small piece that is used to tighten the eye_tracker_angled_arm using an M2 threaded bolt.

eye_cam_arm_brace - connector piece that is used to attach the eye_cam_arm to the eye_tracker_angled_arm.

eye_cam_arm - angled arm that is used to adjust the forward/back (distance) position of the eye tracking camera. The eye_cam_arm also holds attaches to the eye_cam_holder directly.

eye_cam_clamp - small tightening piece to hold the eye_cam_holder rigidly in place

eye_cam_holder - small arm piece into which the eye tracking camera (Microsoft HD-6000 webcam in this case) can be inserted. This holder can be replaced by a holder for other types of cameras as well.

top_plate/arm_plate - small plates used to further tighten the hold the eye_cam_angled_bracket/eye_cam_arm in place.

title: Amazing Bubble Wands!

description.text:
NEW: There is an updated version! The new ones are bigger and better (and some are newer!) Check them out!
Amazing Bubble Wands 2.0 : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1455486

This collection of bubble wands can be printed and used for children 2+! Kids and adults can learn about bubbles! After playing with these, they can learn to create their own bubble wands!

Thanks!
-Caitlin

--------------------------The 11 Bubble Wands-------------------
Simple bubble wand
Target scope bubble wand
3-in-1 circle bubble wand
Turtle bubble wand
Cat bubble wand
Panda bubble wand
Butterfly bubble wand
Ladybug bubble wand
Flower bubble wand
Shooting star bubble wand
Minion bubble wand

-------------------------------------Bubbles------------------------------------
What are bubbles?
Bubbles are created when an air pocket is trapped inside of film from a soapy sphere.

Why are they only spheres?
Even though many of the bubble wands are different shapes, bubbles can only form in a sphere because they are "minimal surface structures", which means that they shrink to the smallest shape they can be for the volume of air it holds.

Why do they pop?
Aside from landing on something pokey, they pop because the water between the soap films evaporates from the sun. That's why when it's colder, bubbles tend to last longer because of the slowed evaporation process and sometimes will freeze.

Why do bubbles stick together?
Bubbles want to have the smallest surface area it can possibly have, so it will share a common wall with another bubble. If there are three bubbles that join together, they will meet at the center at a 120 degree angle!

Where do bubbles get their colors?
Bubbles get their colors from light waves reflecting between the soap film’s outer and inner surfaces. The distance between the layers gets smaller as the water evaporates, making the colors change.

NOTE: I'm not a bubble expert! I got the information from:
http://www.kidsdiscover.com/teacherresources/bubbles-for-kids/

Just download it and print it! No special settings are required!

Using Tinkercad, I created all of these wands using simple shapes and holes. First, I had to come up with ideas of what I was going to create, and then I did it in the next few hours! But of course, I had to remake a few after printing and testing them!

-----------------------------------Soap Recipe--------------------------------
2 cups of warm water
1/4 cup of dish soap
1/4 cup of sugar

Mix 'em all together!

remixed_from.author: walter
remixed_from.title: Tank Extruder Mount (RigidBot, E3Dv6, Printrbot Gear Head)

description.text:
Updated version of this extruder can be found here

This is an experimental extruder design that may be compatible with some Eustathios printers (I'm using Eric Lien's Eustathios v2 Spyder variant). This extruder is designed to switch between bowden, direct drive Gear Head, and direct drive Bondtech using the linked extruder parts. I may redesign it once I have a better idea which configurations I prefer.

The main differences with this extruder are the following:

  • Allows switching between different configurations (bowden, direct drive, bondtech, and gearhead)
  • It is much larger (and heavier), expect to lose about 1cm build area in x and y (significantly more y in BondTech direct drive mode)
  • It is more difficult to assemble and install so I'd recommend starting with one of the other designs if building a new printer
  • Hotend height is higher (this may cause problems with some bed configurations? - I'm using a custom bed configuration)
  • More CFM for part cooling (I prefer to run with more cooling than most)
  • I don't know if the extruder cooling is sufficient for warmer environments or heated build chambers.

See the instructions tab for more info on assembly and parts required.

Filaments:
-- Sainsmart Clear PETG
-- IAP Clear ABS

E3D v6
The E3D v6 is held in place with a M5x30mm screw and an optional M3x40mm screw. The tolerances on the slot for the E3D is tight, and will probably require some light sanding to get a good fit.

Bushings
I'm using 10x14x30mm graphite bushings with a NinjaFlex sleeve, but the holes are 15.9mm in diameter and should be compatible with the more common self aligning bushings. I've found the larger size of the extruder makes it more prone to binding than the original design, at least with the 30mm graphite bushings I'm using. With the original extruder, I was able to slide two 30mm bearings into a single 60mm NinjaFlex sleeve. With this extruder the bushings are further apart and I'm using short 10mm NinjaFlex sleeves (instead of 30mm) to reduce binding.

Extruder Fan
I mounted the extruder fan with 3mm cylindrical magnets, black oxide set screws, and a NinjaFlex gasket. The set screws go in the extruder holes, the magnets press fit in the fan screw holes, and the gasket prevents it from rattling. This makes it very easy to remove, but you can use the standard approach of attaching the fan with some M3 screws.

Cooling Fans
The extruder uses two 50mm x 15mm blower fans for part cooling. I'm using removable glue dots to keep them in place. I rarely run them at 100% (usually only for bridging or very short layer times). Typical values I use are 60-80% for PLA, 0-20% for ABS.

Cooling Duct
The cooling duct is attached using eight M4x3mm black oxide set screws and eight 5mm x 3mm cylindrical magnets. The set screws are screwed into the duct and extruder plastic, and the magnets hold them together (see pictures). Some other sizes can work too as there is some adjustment range with the set screws.

Lights (optional)
I'm using two 2W 12V LED modules* wired in series (I'm running a 24V system) to light up the extruder. I have them wired on a separate circuit and set up to indicate when the hotend is hot enough to extrude.

Brass M3 Press Fit Inserts
The holes on top of the extruder are designed to work with brass press fit threaded inserts.

Printing
I printed the extruder block in PETG and the cooling duct in ABS. I would recommend printing in the default orientation with support. It can be printed on the back corner flat without support (it was originally designed to be printed that way), but I found that the axes were less orthogonal when printed that way (this design is prone to warping and not very tolerant of it).

Wiring
I wired the heater and thermistor on a separate connector from the fans and lights. This makes it easier to switch out just the heater block.
